There are some species of birds that have a small amount of iron located in a sac of fluid in their beaks, (and some species have it in a fluid sac near their ears.)

It accumulates and grows as they get older by being slowly extracted from the iron content in their blood.

It's purpose was a complete mystery until very recently.
Now, the academic, "smart," people who have been studying it, hypothesize that it's purpose is to help them with their migratory patterns by orienting them to true north using the Earth's magnetic field.

Natural selection has made it so the species of birds that have it are more successful, so, more of them live long enough to breed and pass the trait to their offspring than other species.

The bird that can better navigate in it's three dimensional habitat will obviously be a more successful breeder.

The most famous pigeon was one called Cher Ami (french for ''dear friend'). During WWI, it flew several missions and was injured several times. On it's last mission, it was shot down by Germans who had surrounded 200 American soldiers in a french forest. With the canister containing the message dangling from its nearly obliterated leg that was hanging from a tendon, it got back up and flew again delivering the message to tell the US base command telling to stop firing on their own soldiers and come and rescue them. As a result, the lives of 200 soldiers were saved.

Did you know pigeons mate for life? That they can fly over 50mph? And the lowly pigeon is one of the brightest birds on the planet?  And they are used to transport memory cards and messages daily in the Grand Canyon? Digital memory cards are strapped to special harness on the birds and they would fly back to their coop and the pictures would be developed at the home base so that people's pictures would be waiting for them when the photographers down at the bottom of the Canyon returned. http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1224522/Pigeon-post-Meet-birds-backpack-deliver-parcels-time.html Pigeons have saved people's lives in war. http://www.deterapigeon.com/21-amazing-facts-about-pigeons.htm Or looking for people lost at sea. They were trained to spot lifeboats and life jackets as they pecked at a button to set off a light. They were suspended in a harness in a glass bowl-like enclosure on the underside of search planes and helicopters. And because they see better than we do, (and don't get bored as easily as we do) their chances of seeing something humans missed is higher and could be used to save people's lives. http://www.susanscott.net/OceanWatch2001/jun22-01.html 
They even have been used to transport blood, medication, and quickly needs tests across busy cities where the time for them to fly is much faster than a human can go. http://soda.swedish-ict.se/5314/1/976-2558-1-PB.pdf
